Service Bus

Make applications and equipment stay connected across private cloud and public cloud scenarios.

Apply for trial Purchase now

Azure Service Bus is a message transfer infrastructure located among various applications, permitting the applications to exchange messages, so as to expand the scale and improve recovery capabilities.

FAQs

Expand All
  • How is the number of relay messages calculated?

    Every message sent to and from Service Bus Relay is a chargeable message. One message is defined as a data unit equal to or less than 64 KB.

  • How is the number of operating queues and themes calculated?

    For the transfer entity (queue, themes/subscription, message buffer zone), one operation refers to any API call to Service Bus services.

    Sending, receiving or deleting message less than or equal to 64 KB is considered a chargeable operation. If the message size exceeds 64 KB, the chargeable operation can be calculated as a multiple of 64 KB. For instance, one 8 KB message sent to Service Bus is charged as one operation, and one 96 KB message sent to Service Bus is charged as two operations. You can read 8 KB messages by locking, then delete the message and charging as two operations.

    The same message sent several times (e.g.: message is sent to several listeners, or withdrawn after cancellation, delay or failure in mailing) will be taken as individual operations. For instance, if a theme has 3 subscriptions, a 64 KB message sent and then received will be charged by 4 chargeable operations (1 “incoming” and 3 “outgoing” operations, assuming all messages are sent to all subscriptions and deleted after reading).

    You can receive messages by using the ReceiveMode of PeekLock, then deleting the message through full call, which will generate two individual operations. Relocking a message will also generate one operation.

    In addition, creating, reading (listing), updating and deleting queues, themes or subscriptions will also generate operation expenses.

    Operation means API calls to the terminals of queues or themes/subscription services, including management, sending/receiving and session state operations.

    Operation Types Description
    Management Create, read, update and delete queues or themes/subscriptions
    Message Transfer Sending and receiving message by queues or themes/subscriptions
    Session Status Obtain the session status of queues or themes/subscriptions or set the status
  • How do we calculate relay hours?

    The relay hours are charged by the cumulative time when every Service Bus Relay is in an “open” state. When the WCF service (i.e. “Relay Listener”) of an activated relay is connected to the given Service Bus Address (Service Namespace URL) for the first time, the relay will permit implicit instantiation and is opened in the address. The relay will be closed only when the last listener is disconnected from the address. Thus, for the purpose of billing, the relay will be regarded as being in “open” state from the time the first relay listener is connected to the relay’s Service Bus Address to the time when the last relay listener is disconnected from the address.

  • What is transfer connection and what is its billing method?

    Transfer connection is defined as one of the following connections:

    1. AMQP connection from the client to Service Bus themes/subscriptions, queues or Event Hubs.
    2. HTTP call to a receiving message from Service Bus themes or queues with a receiving timeout greater than zero.
      Charging of concurrent transfer connections exceeding the peak of the attached number (standard level is 1,000). Peak value will be measured every hour. Expenses are allocated in proportion to 744 hours every month, and accumulated within the billing cycle of every month. After the end of the billing cycle, the attached number will be applied according to the total peak hours allocated proportionately (1,000 transfer connections every month).
      Instances
      1. You can establish connections with 10,000 devices through one AMQP Connection, receive commands from the Service Bus Themes and send remote-sensing events to the Event Hubs. If all equipment is connected 12 hours per day, you’re required to pay the following connection fees (excluding any other Service Bus fees): 10,000 connections * 12 hours * 31 days/744 = 5,000 transfer connections. After deducting the limit of 1,000 connections/month, you need to pay the fees of 4,000 transfer connections at a rate of ¥0.18/every transfer connection, totaling ¥720.
      2. Timeout is not zero when 10,000 devices receive messages from Service Bus Queues via HTTP. If all equipment is connected 12 hours per day, you’re required to pay the following connection fees (excluding any other Service Bus fees): 10,000 HTTP receiving connections * 12 hours/day * 31 days/744 hours = 5,000 transfer connections.
  • Does the transfer connection fee apply to queues and themes/subscriptions?

    Yes. Sending events by HTTP isn’t required to pay connection fees no matter how many sending systems/devices you use. Receiving events by HTTP with a timeout greater than zero (sometimes called “Long-Poll”) will generate transfer connection fees. No matter whether the connection is used for sending or receiving, the AMQP connection will generate transfer connection fees. Please note, in the basic namespace, you can use at most 100 free transfer connections, which is the maximum transfer connections permitted by every Azure subscription. In every Azure subscription, the first 1,000 transfer connections within any/all standard namespaces are free of charge (not included in basic fees). As these limits are enough to cover many service-to-service programs, there will generally be considerable transfer connection fees only when you plan to use AMQP or HTTP Long-Poll on numerous clients, namely, to realize more efficient event flow or activate two-way communication between thousands of/millions of devices or application instances.

  • If my Azure subscription has multiple standard namespaces, are you charging me the basic fees several times?

    No. Every Azure subscription is only required to pay the monthly basic fees of a message transfer Standard Edition. This means that after you create a Standard level Service Bus Namespace, you will be able to create any number of standard level namespaces in the same Azure subscription, without generating any additional basic fees.

    For other common questions about Service Bus Billing, please refer to MSDN articles.

  • What’s a mixed connection?

    Mixed connection can help establish two-way binary stream communication between two networked applications, one or two of which can remain behind NAT or a firewall. You can implement listener receiving “Relay” connections and transmitter sending “Relay” connections, provided that you adopt any language supporting basic WebSocket functions (including the WebSocket API of most web browsers).

  • How is a mixed connection billed?

    When creating the first mixed connection listener, you shall pay the expenses according to the rate of every listener unit. Every individual listener to be created is charged by using the same rate. The services include 5 GB free data transmission every month. You can use this 5 GB free data transmission in all listener units. If the total data transmissions among all listener units exceed 5 GB, the extra data transmission is charged.

    Pricing example 1: If a listener has been installed (e.g.: a mixed connection manager instance) and has run continuously one month, and also sent 3 GB data across the connection, the total expenses are ¥76.09.

    Pricing example 2: If a listener has been installed (e.g.: a mixed connection manager instance) and has run continuously one month, and also sent 10 GB data across the connection, the total expenses are ¥143.077: ¥76.087 (connection and first 5 GB) + ¥66.99 (extra 5 GB data).

    Pricing example 3: If the instances of two mixed connection managers (A and B) have been installed and have run continuously one month, and also sent 3 GB data across connection A and 6 GB data across connection B, the total expenses are ¥205.766: ¥76.087 (connection A) + ¥76.087 (connection B) + ¥53.592 (4 GB excess data due to connection A 3 GB + connection B 6 GB).

  • Is there a data transmission fee for connection to the mixed connection listener?

    Every connection to the listener is charged with the fee for 64 KB. The aforementioned data size will be deducted from 5 GB provided free of charge to the listener unit every month. The listener unit fee is calculated every hour by taking 5 minutes as the increment. Multiple opening and closing for the purpose of development/testing is not charged.

  • How long does the mixed connection listener stay open if there is no data transmission? How much is the fee we pay for keeping the connection open?

    If the connection is opened but hasn’t transmitted any data, we will transmit 1KB every minute to keep connection available on your behalf. This aims to prevent the network from being disconnected automatically every a few minutes.

Support and Service Level Agreements

If you have any questions or need any help, please access Azure Support and select self-help service or any other method to contact us for support.

For Service Bus Relay, we guarantee that at least 99.9% time, the applications configured correctly can establish connections with the deployed relay.

For the Service Bus queues and themes, we guarantee that at least 99.9% time, the applications configured correctly can send or receive message or perform other operations on the deployed queues or themes.

To learn more about the details of our server level agreement, please visit the Service Level Agreement page.
